segment.source: Network access Sharing and security model for local accounts (Windows 10)
segment.target: Network access Sharing and security model for local accounts (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network access Sharing and security model for local accounts security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network access Sharing and security model for local accounts security policy setting.

segment.source: Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts
segment.target: Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts security policy setting.

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: This policy setting determines how network logons that use local accounts are authenticated.
segment.target: This policy setting determines how network logons that use local accounts are authenticated.

segment.source: If you configure this policy setting to Classic, network logons that use local account credentials authenticate with those credentials.
segment.target: If you configure this policy setting to Classic, network logons that use local account credentials authenticate with those credentials.

segment.source: If you configure this policy setting to Guest only, network logons that use local accounts are automatically mapped to the Guest account.
segment.target: If you configure this policy setting to Guest only, network logons that use local accounts are automatically mapped to the Guest account.

segment.source: The Classic model provides precise control over access to resources, and it enables you to grant different types of access to different users for the same resource.
segment.target: The Classic model provides precise control over access to resources, and it enables you to grant different types of access to different users for the same resource.

segment.source: Conversely, the Guest only model treats all users equally, and they all receive the same level of access to a given resource, which can be either Read Only or Modify.
segment.target: Conversely, the Guest only model treats all users equally, and they all receive the same level of access to a given resource, which can be either Read Only or Modify.

segment.source: Note: This policy setting does not affect network logons that use domain accounts.
segment.target: Note: This policy setting does not affect network logons that use domain accounts.

segment.source: Nor does this policy setting affect interactive logons that are performed remotely through services such as Telnet or Remote Desktop Services.
segment.target: Nor does this policy setting affect interactive logons that are performed remotely through services such as Telnet or Remote Desktop Services.

segment.source: When the device is not joined to a domain, this policy setting also tailors the Sharing and Security tabs in Windows Explorer to correspond to the sharing and security model that is being used.
segment.target: When the device is not joined to a domain, this policy setting also tailors the Sharing and Security tabs in Windows Explorer to correspond to the sharing and security model that is being used.

segment.source: When the value of this policy setting is Guest only - local users authenticate as Guest, any user who can access your device over the network does so with Guest user rights.
segment.target: When the value of this policy setting is Guest only - local users authenticate as Guest, any user who can access your device over the network does so with Guest user rights.

segment.source: This means that they will probably be unable to write to shared folders.
segment.target: This means that they will probably be unable to write to shared folders.

segment.source: Although this does increase security, it makes it impossible for authorized users to access shared resources on those systems.
segment.target: Although this does increase security, it makes it impossible for authorized users to access shared resources on those systems.

segment.source: When the value is Classic - local users authenticate as themselves, local accounts must be password-protected; otherwise, anyone can use those user accounts to access shared system resources.
segment.target: When the value is Classic - local users authenticate as themselves, local accounts must be password-protected; otherwise, anyone can use those user accounts to access shared system resources.

segment.source: Possible values
segment.target: Possible values

segment.source: Classic - Local users authenticate as themselves
segment.target: Classic - Local users authenticate as themselves

segment.source: Guest only - Local users authenticate as Guest
segment.target: Guest only - Local users authenticate as Guest

segment.source: Not defined
segment.target: Not defined

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: For network servers, set this policy to Classic - local users authenticate as themselves.
segment.target: For network servers, set this policy to Classic - local users authenticate as themselves.

segment.source: On end-user systems, set this policy to Guest only - local users authenticate as Guest.
segment.target: On end-user systems, set this policy to Guest only - local users authenticate as Guest.

segment.source: Location
segment.target: Location

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: Policy management
segment.target: Policy management

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Restart requirement
segment.target: Restart requirement

segment.source: None.
segment.target: None.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Group Policy
segment.target: Group Policy

segment.source: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
segment.target: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).

segment.source: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.
segment.target: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.

segment.source: Security considerations
segment.target: Security considerations

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: With the Guest only model, any user who can authenticate to your device over the network does so with Guest privileges, which probably means that they do not have Write access to shared resources on that device.
segment.target: With the Guest only model, any user who can authenticate to your device over the network does so with Guest privileges, which probably means that they do not have Write access to shared resources on that device.

segment.source: Although this restriction does increase security, it makes it more difficult for authorized users to access shared resources on those computers because ACLs on those resources must include access control entries (ACEs) for the Guest account.
segment.target: Although this restriction does increase security, it makes it more difficult for authorized users to access shared resources on those computers because ACLs on those resources must include access control entries (ACEs) for the Guest account.

segment.source: With the Classic model, local accounts should be password protected.
segment.target: With the Classic model, local accounts should be password protected.

segment.source: Otherwise, if Guest access is enabled, anyone can use those user accounts to access shared system resources.
segment.target: Otherwise, if Guest access is enabled, anyone can use those user accounts to access shared system resources.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: For network servers, configure the Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts setting to Classic – local users authenticate as themselves.
segment.target: For network servers, configure the Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts setting to Classic – local users authenticate as themselves.

segment.source: On end-user computers, configure this policy setting to Guest only – local users authenticate as guest.
segment.target: On end-user computers, configure this policy setting to Guest only – local users authenticate as guest.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: None.
segment.target: None.

segment.source: This is the default configuration.
segment.target: This is the default configuration.
